history.content:
I'd prefer Option 1 as it gradually builds up your aptitude while not making any of the semesters too challenging.
Also, I don't think EECS 127 would be too helpful for you, given your interests. Maybe look at CS 152 - Computer Architecture instead?

As title suggests, I would greatly appreciate some advice in formulating a solid tentative schedule; I believe I have a very high level understanding of what I want to focus in, but I feel lost when it comes to which order to take the classes, and whether the classes are even a good fit!

With the following in mind, I have created a few tentative plans that are shown below, but as you may see, the order in which I have things laid out is preetty arbitrary :/.

  1. My plan w.r.t. the path I would like to take is this: build a foundation in controls & cyberphysical systems as well as digitial design & computer architecture. I figured that this would give me the skills to model a system that may demand very high performance (speed, power consumption, etc.), as well as realize that design at a H/W level, optimizing for the task at hand (Is this even how things work? Also sorry if my technical vocabulary/jargon is very poor).
  2. I want to maximize my chances of obtaining some experience in research/industry (more likely the latter, as I hope to use any money from this to fund tuition in Fall '21) NEXT summer. Which classes will help this cause? Should I even be thinking this way?
  3. I took special care to make sure I do not overload myself in any one semester. Do any of these terms look too heavy? I know 151 is infamous for its course load/final project. For reference, my first semester here at Cal I took 16a/61a/cs70, and despite being pressed for time a select few weeks, I managed to do pretty well by my standards.
  4. As for EECS 151, I don't know which lab section better suits what I am looking for: the ASIC lab or FPGA lab.

*NOTE* I am planning to take CS 61C this summer.

Thank you very much for your time. Any advice, anecdotes, etc. is greatly appreciated :)
history.subject: Junior Transfer - Schedule Help!
